word-pahau.name: pahau
word-pahau.desc: [aupa](word-aupa) et [pahau](word-pahau) sont la même chose exprimés depuis des lieux un peu différents. La gratitude et le pardon, c'est pareil. Pardonner [pahau](word-pahau) c'est enfin recevoir ce qui nous est arrivé (et ce qu'on a fait), c'est un peu lié au passé. La gratitude, c'est recevoir le présent [aupa](word-aupa). La confiance, c'est recevoir le temps entier [augu](word-augu) (passé, présent, avenir), accepter le processus de vie.

card-aaa.name: aaa
card-aaa.desc:
My first goal was to create a language for love and sex. Something that would
make it easy and fun to express desire, play with power exchanges and honor
the great gift of sharing bodily love.

I also felt that the languages I speak had lots of biais in terms of what is
expected. For example, we have verbs to express penetration but we have no
words to express "grasping with the vagina" ([1](phrase-1)  or "kissing with the vulva" ([2](phrase-2)).

I wanted to have these words so I started to work on a language that would
focus on the body.

As I worked on the language while going through difficult mental states, I
discovered that creating words helped me better understand what I was going
through so I added many words to explore the feelings of awe and terror one 
feels in being alive.

So here is **Keoda**, a language born in the realm of sexuality, evolved as a
way of coping through mental illness and blossomed in the poetic realm as a
way to express my awe at being alive, [iwigui](word-iwigui)...

This language helps me on my path to self-acceptance and love.

My hope by sharing it is that some of the confusions and weird notions of
this poetic endeavour might echo in someone's heart and help validate this
person's feelings.

I feel utterly weird.

I hope you do too, dear reader ❤️️

PS: Some pages have not yet been translated to english, thanks for your
patience: this whole thing is a work in progress...

Your next read ? [kdana](card-kdana) or [verbs](card-verbs)
card-aaa.fulltext:
aaa 
My first goal was to create a language for love and sex. Something that would
make it easy and fun to express desire, play with power exchanges and honor
the great gift of sharing bodily love.

I also felt that the languages I speak had lots of biais in terms of what is
expected. For example, we have verbs to express penetration but we have no
words to express "grasping with the vagina" ([1](phrase-1)  or "kissing with the vulva" ([2](phrase-2)).

I wanted to have these words so I started to work on a language that would
focus on the body.

As I worked on the language while going through difficult mental states, I
discovered that creating words helped me better understand what I was going
through so I added many words to explore the feelings of awe and terror one 
feels in being alive.

So here is **Keoda**, a language born in the realm of sexuality, evolved as a
way of coping through mental illness and blossomed in the poetic realm as a
way to express my awe at being alive, [iwigui](word-iwigui)...

This language helps me on my path to self-acceptance and love.

My hope by sharing it is that some of the confusions and weird notions of
this poetic endeavour might echo in someone's heart and help validate this
person's feelings.

I feel utterly weird.

I hope you do too, dear reader ❤️️

PS: Some pages have not yet been translated to english, thanks for your
patience: this whole thing is a work in progress...

Your next read ? [kdana](card-kdana) or [verbs](card-verbs)
 Why keoda ?

card-counting.name: counting
card-counting.desc:
Here are the number from 1 to 10:

* [dji](word-dji) (10)
* [da](word-da) (9)
* [je](word-je) (8)
* [fe](word-fe) (7)
* [shi](word-shi) (6)
* [lil](word-lil) (5)
* [ka](word-ka) (4)
* [pe](word-pe) (3)
* [de](word-de) (2)
* [pi](word-pi) (1)

The powers of ten:

* [ipi](word-ipi) (10)
* [ipa](word-ipa) (100)
* [ipu](word-ipu) (1000).

## Some examples:

* [3](phrase-3)
* or [4](phrase-4)
* or [5](phrase-5)
* [6](phrase-6)
* [7](phrase-7)
* [8](phrase-8)
* [9](phrase-9)

## Big numbers !

* 1000^2: [10](phrase-10)
* 1000^3: [11](phrase-11)
* 1000^4: [12](phrase-12)

We can also express powers of ten [13](phrase-13).

## Small numbers

* 10^-1: [14](phrase-14)
* 10^-2: [15](phrase-15)
* 10^-3: [16](phrase-16)

card-genders.name: genders
card-genders.desc:
Keoda does not have mandatory gender for conjugation or pronouns but the notion still exists as the following adjectives:

* [ana](word-ana) (tree / feminine)
* [iwi](word-iwi) (bird / non-binary)
* [oto](word-oto) (wind / masculine)

And as with all adjecives, they can be combined:

* [anoto](word-anoto)
* [aniwi](word-aniwi)
* [iwana](word-iwana)
* [iwoto](word-iwoto)
* [otana](word-otana)
* [otiwi](word-otiwi)
card-genders.fulltext:
genders

And as with all adjecives, they can be combined:

* [anoto](word-anoto)
* [aniwi](word-aniwi)
* [iwana](word-iwana)
* [iwoto](word-iwoto)
* [otana](word-otana)
* [otiwi](word-otiwi)

card-gunes.name: gunes
card-gunes.desc:
# The scale of [gu](word-gu)

These states correspond to increasing intensity of [gu](word-gu) and if they are
not balanced by increasing practicality and material humility [nunes](card-nunes),
they are just other names for hubris or psychosis.

## The euphoric states

These need to be balanced with their equivalent [nunes](card-nunes) states.

* 10 [djipa](word-djipa) (remembering being god.des) <=> [djifi](word-djifi) (humble)
* 9 [dapa](word-dapa) (joy) <=> [dafi](word-dafi) (serving)
* 8 [jepa](word-jepa) (belonging) <=> [jefi](word-jefi) (caring)
* 7 [fepa](word-fepa) (pride) <=> [fefi](word-fefi) (adapting)
* 6 [shipa](word-shipa) (believing) <=> [shifi](word-shifi) (learning)

## The "territorial" states.

From here, the states are more difficult. These states are shared on both
[gu](word-gu) and [nu](word-nu) scales.

* 5 [nelil](word-nelil) (confusion/insecure)
* 4 [neka](word-neka) (shame/restless)
* 3 [nepe](word-nepe) (limbo/offensive)
* 2 [nede](word-nede) (anguish/fighting)

## And this is hell

* 1 [nepi](word-nepi) (division/fragmented)

card-kdana.name: kdana
card-kdana.desc:
# Geography

The land of keotians is simply [gana](word-gana), the spirit-thing.

The land is mostly made of islands, volcanoes and small mountains with a
gentle climate (when there are no storms).

Because survival does not require huge amounts of time and effort, the
keotians have had lots of time to enjoy the views of children, arts and
...[zuzu](word-zuzu) which is an important part of their culture.

Bodily love is seen as a way to connect hearts and even though there are
many elements related to power exchange, these are seen as ways to
create bonding, trust or simply as a way to explore the self [pi](word-pi).

[17](phrase-17)

kdana

card-nunes.name: nunes
card-nunes.desc:
# The scale of [nu](word-nu)

These states correspond to increasing levels of humility and practicality
[nu](word-nu). They are not "feelings" but how the person is perceived by others
(all others, not just close friends).

## The "flowing" states

These are the difficult (pragmatic) states that need to be cultivated to
balance their equivalent [gunes](card-gunes) (poetic) states.

On their own they can feel dreadful if not enlightenend by some purpose given
by the poetic states. Balancing serves both ways.

* 10 [djifi](word-djifi) (humble) <=> [djipa](word-djipa) (remembering being god.dess)
* 9 [dafi](word-dafi) (serving) <=> [dapa](word-dapa) (joy)
* 8 [jefi](word-jefi) (caring) <=> [jepa](word-jepa) (belonging)
* 7 [fefi](word-fefi) (adapting) <=> [fepa](word-fepa) (pride)
* 6 [shifi](word-shifi) (learning) <=> [shipa](word-shipa) (believing)

## The "territorial" states

These states are the same as the ones on the spirit scale [gunes](card-gunes).

* 5 [nelil](word-nelil) (confusion/insecure)
* 4 [neka](word-neka) (shame/restless)
* 3 [nepe](word-nepe) (limbo/offensive)
* 2 [nede](word-nede) (anguish/fighting)

## And this is hell

* 1 [nepi](word-nepi) (division/fragmented)

card-order.name: order
card-order.desc:
Word order does not matter in a phrase so that we can put emphasis and
expectation on any part of the phrase. For example, we can say:

(You need to say these out loud, emphasis on "DOM"...)
[18](phrase-18)

Or

(Again, emphasis on "... DOM !")
[19](phrase-19)

Or even
[20](phrase-20)

Or

[20](phrase-20)
 Word order

card-verbs.name: verbs
card-verbs.desc:
Many nouns are also verbs such as [fa](word-fa) or [fen](word-fen).

This language was born from an imaginary place where love making is one of the most important activity of adults and this results in a rich vocabulary to talk about caressing, slapping, pinching and playing with body parts.

# [i](word-i), [u](word-u), [o](word-o) suffix

These alter the verbs respectively to mean "caressing" or gentle, "pinching" and slapping or hurting.

* [21](phrase-21)
* [22](phrase-22)
* [23](phrase-23)

The very first use of the language was to ask a sexual partner to do something so the imperative form is the simplest and looks like the infinitiv.

Phrase do not have precise verb, subject or object positioning and conjugation is used to remove ambiguity.

If the first noun does not match conjugation, this means that it represents the adverb (receiver of an action):

* [24](phrase-24)
* which is a short form of [25](phrase-25)
* and we can also say [26](phrase-26)

It really depends where we want to put the emphasis (on the kissing or on who is to be kissed).

# Conjugation

For other tenses apart from imperative, the conjugation *comes first*. This is because it is an evolution
from *subject verb* to *subjectverb*:

* [27](phrase-27)
* evolved into [28](phrase-28)

So the possible conjugations are the same as the possible subjects:

* [o](word-o) *I/we* (1SG.INDF)
* [i](word-i) *you* (2SG)
* [a](word-a) *them* (3SG)
* [sho](word-sho) *us* (present) (1PL.PRS)
* [shi](word-shi) *you* (present) (2PL.PRS)
* [sha](word-sha) *them* (3PL)

## And the rarer forms

* [okei](word-okei) *I honorific* (1SG.HONOR)
* [kei](word-kei) *honorific* (2SG.HONOR)
* [akei](word-akei) *they honorific* (3SG.HONOR)
* [piyi](word-piyi) *me depraved* (1SG.DPRV)
* [yi](word-yi) *you depraved* (2SG.DPRV)
* [pi](word-pi) *I* (1SG)
* [de](word-de) *us two* (1PL.DU)
* [pe](word-pe) *some* (3PL.INDF)
* [ka](word-ka) *us all* (1PL.DEF)

## Passive voices

This is used to highlight the receiver of the action and allows us to not
say anything about the doer, as in

[29](phrase-29)

This conjugation is created by adding [e](word-e) prefix and later became [zo](word-zo) instead of [eho](word-eho). Think "Be I whipped".

For most common cases, the language evolved from *eho*, *ehi* and *eha* to:

* [zo](word-zo) *I/we passiv* (1SG.INDF.PAS)
* [zi](word-zi) *you passiv* (2SG.PAS)
* [zo](word-zo) *they passiv* (3SG.PAS)

## Honorific / depraved

This is super important and super important and super important. In many role
play it is great to have Dom/sub relationships, one that is in control and
another who is passive. In order to emphasise this setting, the Dominant is
referred to as "fantastic" [kei](word-kei) and the sub as "tiny" [yi](word-yi) or "wet" [lo](word-lo).

This translates in possesive suffix [tei](word-tei), [tiyi](alt-tiyi), [tilo](word-tilo) or conjugations using [kei](word-kei) or the affix [ei](word-ei) or [yi](word-yi).

[30](phrase-30)
[31](phrase-31)

Just remember, what sounds like "OK" is in fact "I-fantastic".

# Tenses

The tense is marked by a suffix related to time. There are a lot of them
because these timings are so important in the erotic situations where this
language originated.

## Future tenses

* [lire](word-lire) (FUT.EVNT) eventual future
* [liro](word-liro) (FUT.DIST) distant future
* [liru](word-liru) (FUT.PROX) close future
* [lira](word-lira) (FUT.CRAS) tomorrow
* [liri](word-liri) (FUT.HOD) tonight or next morning

## Past tenses

* [lemi](word-lemi) (PST.HOD) last night or this morning
* [lema](word-lema) (PST.HEST) yesterday
* [lemu](word-lemu) (PST.PROX) recent past
* [lemo](word-lemo) (PST.DIST) distant past
* [leme](word-leme) (PST.EVNT) eventual past

## Eternal tenses

* [lei](word-lei) (DEF) always
* [nei](word-nei) (NEG) never

# Examples

* [32](phrase-32)
* [33](phrase-33)

card-verbs.fulltext:
verbs 
Many nouns are also verbs such as [fa](word-fa) or [fen](word-fen).

This language was born from an imaginary place where love making is one of the most important activity of adults and this results in a rich vocabulary to talk about caressing, slapping, pinching and playing with body parts.

# [i](word-i), [u](word-u), [o](word-o) suffix

These alter the verbs respectively to mean "caressing" or gentle, "pinching" and slapping or hurting.

* [21](phrase-21)
* [22](phrase-22)
* [23](phrase-23)

The very first use of the language was to ask a sexual partner to do something so the imperative form is the simplest and looks like the infinitiv.

Phrase do not have precise verb, subject or object positioning and conjugation is used to remove ambiguity.

If the first noun does not match conjugation, this means that it represents the adverb (receiver of an action):

* [24](phrase-24)
* which is a short form of [25](phrase-25)
* and we can also say [26](phrase-26)

It really depends where we want to put the emphasis (on the kissing or on who is to be kissed).

# Conjugation

For other tenses apart from imperative, the conjugation *comes first*. This is because it is an evolution
from *subject verb* to *subjectverb*:

* [27](phrase-27)
* evolved into [28](phrase-28)

So the possible conjugations are the same as the possible subjects:

* [o](word-o) *I/we* (1SG.INDF)
* [i](word-i) *you* (2SG)
* [a](word-a) *them* (3SG)
* [sho](word-sho) *us* (present) (1PL.PRS)
* [shi](word-shi) *you* (present) (2PL.PRS)
* [sha](word-sha) *them* (3PL)

## And the rarer forms

* [okei](word-okei) *I honorific* (1SG.HONOR)

* [akei](word-akei) *they honorific* (3SG.HONOR)
* [piyi](word-piyi) *me depraved* (1SG.DPRV)
* [yi](word-yi) *you depraved* (2SG.DPRV)
* [pi](word-pi) *I* (1SG)
* [de](word-de) *us two* (1PL.DU)
* [pe](word-pe) *some* (3PL.INDF)
* [ka](word-ka) *us all* (1PL.DEF)

## Passive voices

This is used to highlight the receiver of the action and allows us to not
say anything about the doer, as in

[29](phrase-29)

This conjugation is created by adding [e](word-e) prefix and later became [zo](word-zo) instead of [eho](word-eho). Think "Be I whipped".

For most common cases, the language evolved from *eho*, *ehi* and *eha* to:

* [zo](word-zo) *I/we passiv* (1SG.INDF.PAS)
* [zi](word-zi) *you passiv* (2SG.PAS)
* [zo](word-zo) *they passiv* (3SG.PAS)

## Honorific / depraved

This is super important and super important and super important. In many role
play it is great to have Dom/sub relationships, one that is in control and
another who is passive. In order to emphasise this setting, the Dominant is
referred to as "fantastic" [kei](word-kei) and the sub as "tiny" [yi](word-yi) or "wet" [lo](word-lo).

This translates in possesive suffix [tei](word-tei), [tiyi](alt-tiyi), [tilo](word-tilo) or conjugations using [kei](word-kei) or the affix [ei](word-ei) or [yi](word-yi).

[30](phrase-30)
[31](phrase-31)

Just remember, what sounds like "OK" is in fact "I-fantastic".

# Tenses

The tense is marked by a suffix related to time. There are a lot of them
because these timings are so important in the erotic situations where this

## Future tenses

* [lire](word-lire) (FUT.EVNT) eventual future
* [liro](word-liro) (FUT.DIST) distant future
* [liru](word-liru) (FUT.PROX) close future
* [lira](word-lira) (FUT.CRAS) tomorrow

## Past tenses

phrase-17.phrase: On earth, we enjoy the mystery of love making.

phrase-34.phrase: La Nature et un temple où de vivants piliers
phrase-34.fulltext: 34 tu gupa ahe agaukida don namel oda

phrase-35.phrase: Laissent parfois sortir de confuses paroles;

phrase-36.phrase: L'homme y passe à travers des forêts de symboles
phrase-36.fulltext: 36 tu yosa afen roa jana lom lana

phrase-37.phrase: Qui l'observent avec des regards familiers.
phrase-37.fulltext: 37 di ko gi sha fa lae

phrase-38.phrase: Comme de longs échos qui de loin se confondent...
phrase-38.fulltext: 38 si agade uki di ha uya es sha nelil
